#Text=WHERE THE CAR TURNS AT 18TH
#Text=This will be a homing pigeon story .
#Text=Though I send it ever so far -- though its destination be the office of a home-and-fireside magazine or one of the kind with a French story in the back , it will return to me .

#Text=After each flight its feathers will be a little more rumpled , its wings more weary , its course more wavering , until , battered , spent , broken , it will flutter to rest in the waste basket .
#Text=And yet , though its message may never be delivered , it must be sent , because -- well , because -- --
#Text=You know where the car turns at Eighteenth ?
#Text=There you see a glaringly attractive billboard poster .
#Text=It depicts groups of smiling , white-clad men standing on tropical shores , with waving palms overhead , and a glimpse of blue sea in the distance .
#Text=The wording beneath the picture runs something like this :
#Text=" Young men wanted .

#Text=Our paper had it that  Edwin Houghton had accepted a position as clerk and assistant chemist at the Kunz drugstore , where he would take up his new duties Monday . "

column1: #Text=His new duties seemed , at first , to consist of opening the store in the morning , sweeping out , and whizzing about town on a bicycle with an unnecessarily insistent bell , delivering prescriptions which had been telephoned for .
#Text=But by the time the summer had really set in Eddie was installed back of the soda fountain .
#Text=There never was anything better looking than Eddie Houghton in his white duck coat .
#Text=He was one of those misleadingly gold and pink and white men .
#Text=I say misleadingly because you usually associate pink-and-whiteness with such words as sissy and mollycoddle .
#Text=Eddie was neither .
#Text=He had played quarter-back every year from his freshman year , and he could putt the shot and cut classes with the best of ' em .

#Text=But in that white duck coat with the braiding and frogs he had any musical-comedy , white-flannel tenor lieutenant whose duty it is to march down to the edge of the footlights , snatch out his sword , and warble about his country 's flag , looking like a flat-nosed , blue-gummed Igorrote .
#Text=Kunz 's soda water receipts swelled to double their usual size , and the girls ' complexions were something awful that summer .
#Text=I 've known Nellie Donovan to take as many as three ice cream sodas and two phosphates a day when Eddie was mixing .
#Text=He had a way of throwing in a good-natured smile , and an easy flow of conversation with every drink .
#Text=While indulging in a little airy persiflage the girls had a great little trick of pursing their mouths into rosebud shapes over their soda straws , and casting their eyes upward at Eddie .
#Text=They all knew the trick , and its value , so that at night Eddie 's dreams were haunted by whole rows of rosily pursed lips , and seas of upturned , adoring eyes .

#Text=Of course we all noticed that on those rare occasions when Josie Morehouse came into Kunz 's her glass was heaped higher with ice cream than that of any of the other girls , and that Eddie 's usually easy flow of talk was interspersed with certain stammerings and stutterings .
#Text=But Josie did n't come in often .
#Text=She had a lot of dignity for a girl of eighteen .
#Text=Besides , she was taking the teachers ' examinations that summer , when the other girls were playing tennis and drinking sodas .
#Text=Eddie really hated the soda water end of the business , as every soda clerk in the world does .
#Text=But he went about it good-naturedly .

#Text=He really wanted to learn the drug business , but the boss knew he had a drawing card , and insisted that Eddie go right on concocting faerie queens and strawberry sundaes , and nectars and Kunz 's specials .

#Text=One Saturday , when he happened to have on hand an over-supply of bananas that would have spoiled over Sunday , he invented a mess and called it the Eddie Extra , and the girls swarmed on it like flies around a honey pot .
#Text=That kind of thing would have spoiled most boys .
#Text=But Eddie had a sensible mother .

#Text=On those nights when he used to come home nauseated with dealing out chop suey sundaes and orangeades , and saying that there was no future for a fellow in our dead little hole , his mother would give him something rather special for supper , and set him hoeing and watering the garden .

#Text=So Eddie stuck to his job , and waited , and all the time he was saying , with a melting look , to the last silly little girl who was drinking her third soda , " Somebody looks mighty sweet in pink to-day , " or while he was doping to-morrow 's ball game with one of the boys who dropped in for a cigar , he was thinking of bigger things , and longing for a man-size job .
#Text=The man-size job loomed up before Eddie 's dazzled eyes when he least expected it .
#Text=It was at the close of a particularly hot day when it seemed to Eddie that every one in town had had everything from birch beer to peach ice cream .
#Text=On his way home to supper he stopped at the postoffice with a handful of letters that old man Kunz had given him to mail .
#Text=His mother had told him that they would have corn out of their own garden for supper that night , and Eddie was in something of a hurry .
#Text=He and his mother were great pals .
